issue.title: Cairo's "set_dash" wants list, not an arrayref
issue.body:
In `Graphics::Primitive::Driver::Cairo 0.46`, there are 5 occurrences of `$context->set_dash(0, [])` (and 6th is missing after line 272).

But, the `set_dash` expects list, not an arrayref. 

As a result, in page content streams of PDF files, created with `Chart::Clicker` (even though only solid lines were used in charts), there are lines like `[ 58810260 58810260] 0 d` which set **huge** (many kilometers) dashes and gaps  -- those numbers originally were memory addresses ;). 

Most software either silently ignores, or maybe tries to draw very long dash, and path of course ends before gap -- therefore lines look solid.

However, at least some software reports PDF files as broken. E.g. Adobe's InDesign refuses to place them. Acrobat opens them OK, but built-in optimizer refuses to optimize (checked with old i.e. around 2012 versions).

I think the 6 lines should be changed to `$context->set_dash(0)`.

inline CSS hack to make error msg more readable

buncha jslint fixes, put in place code (some commented out) for switching over timeline handling to list widget. Need to discuss/coordinate templates, etc more w/ @funkatron
made the scroll to top smooth again. Whatever kinks it had before it's good now
set loglevel to 0 in anticipation of 1.1.0 App Catalog release

fixed issue where template name is not passed in when dashboard is updated
Fix for syntax error in user-detail-assistant.js

search results now have rounded avatar images

Added donation info and updated copyright year to 2010

tiny little debugging statement inserted into sc.helpers.markAllAsRead(); will go away in next SpazCore build

fixed typo and added message explaining setInterval remapping

Rewrote most of the app-assistant and related code to be more flexible, handle launching of bg notifications. Lots of work on background notifications via alarms, but IS BUGGY and disabled by default via hidden pref
started new class to handle background notifications
new template for bg notification counts
changes to make dashboard notifications work with different kinds of data
modifications to work with lawnchair-based model
modifications to work with lawnchair-based model

started passing types for showPostPanel (needed for cursor positioning)
implemented tweets model with Lawnchair; added a couple user saving methods

added check to enable/disable posting on Enter

added code to implement the hold menu on timelines
fixed bug where long contents of spaz-row would overflow
fixed incorrect ref in templates to SC_created_at_unixtime

- v1.0.0

- added some command menu buttons to MessageDetail
- changed Laconi.ca references to StatusNet
- set up cancelling of top event after hold event inbintTimelineEntryTaps

- changed path to media.js file needed for audio and video objects

-Changed JSON decode helper to dump a sch.warn()

-Some CSS changes to make rounded corners across the board

-new spazcore
-Splash page reformatted to fit Pixi screen resolution

- v 0.5.11
- modified error message when DM can't be pulled from cache
- No audio cues played, anywhere
- UI prefs for audio and vibration removed

- removed some comment cruft

- added view-image scene

- 0.5.10
- restored scroll to new message on refresh

- still 0.5.9

-0.5.9
- fixed bugs in TempCache that were causing lockups
- override the MyTimeline removeExtraItems method so we can remove each message type independently (per previous behavior)
- Clear Cache button in prefs now clears the TempCache (old caching is deprecated).
- removed some cruft

-0.5.8
- moved tempcache stuff to its own model

- error reporter should correctly report timeouts
- new SpazCore
- re-enabled New Scene Card menu options

- added view menus and removed page headers from all scenes
- some tweaking of timeline CSS
- new v SpazCore
- deleted a couple large, unused image files

- big refactor of User identification; user accounts now all have a .userid hash which is used to uniquely identify
- temp runtime cache now used; much faster than db-stored caching of timelines
- no cached timelines between starts. This should be fixed.

- reverted spazcore-webos.js build to previous one; seems to fix issue with prefs not loading on start
- v0.5.6

- rewrote much of my-timeline to use SpazTimeline
- big caching changes; not doing same persistent large caching between app calls. will build something smaller back in
- more UI tweaks
- version 0.5.5
- broke prefs somehow? Not loading on my emulator for some reason
fixed scrollToTop functionality to jump to top and halt additional scrolling
- removed .gitmodules because we're not using the spazcore submodule anymore
- manually entering thynctank's changes to app/view/templates.js b/c of some git merging weirdness

- created vendors/ subdir and moved 3rd party libs into it
- started using view menu again in many scenes
- spazcore updated

trying to re-point submodule to public URL
fixed improper check for Spaz namespace in spaz.js

This is "RTM" 0.5.2

- sound pref should now apply to notification alert sound

- fixed double-opening/closing drawer in user detail

- got passing back from file picker working, so photo posting via mail should work

changed sendEmail to take a controller object (Mojo.serviceRequest aint gonna work no mo)

verified email sends correctly, user must trigger send

- added space after replies and dms when prepped

- a little more dump debugging
- fix where 'false' objects weren't being properly detected in rendering loop

- removed a couple Mojo.Timing calls

0.4.3

- Enter in the password field now submits a new account for verification
- v0.3.14

- moved my-timeline filter menu button to top-right; uses custom smaller button
- version 0.3.13
turned off logEvents and upped to v 0.3.12

- set version as 0.3.10

- removed alert debugging from search results

- fixed display of user timeline on user detail

removed http:// from support URLs because loader for browser service prepends it

- added 32x32 icon of spaz star for help scene

- added prescribed Help/Support scene from Palm

- added missing .die() in search assistant

- trying jQuery 1.3.2
a little more commenting for the list event handlers in the start scene
fixed weirdness with trends display and trends spinner; added update trends button

minor CSS changes in new account panel; show version # on splash; minor formatting changes in About
commented out note for Twitter API Base URL pref

timeline and this.tweetsModel

comments.body: Why not use .toggleClassName() instead and save some DOM lookups with this.controller.get('panel') only once executed?
I don't see a reason off the top of my head not to.
This fixes the "post the DM text with the message" bug.

issue.title: Make it work with Twitter API 1.1
issue.body: I patched Spaz for webOS  to make it compatible with Twitter's API 1.1. Please make an update in the AppCatalog. There are still Spaz users with webOS phones :)

issue.title: Search in Followers/Friends
issue.body: It would be great if one could filter the shown contacts in the follower/friends views. E.g. start typing "a" and all contacts without "a" in username or name get filtered out of the list.

issue.title: Top-level "Show User" menu item
issue.body: Currently, the process to look up an account that the current user isn't following requires a trip through the search interface. There should be a simple interface to provide a username, and see that user's profile.

issue.title: Message detail should have an "expand links" option
issue.body: When viewing an individual message's detail info, there should be an option to expand shortened URLs embedded in it. Once expanded, the links in the message should probably be visually marked to indicate that they were changed from the original.

issue.title: It show a blank card when I launch spaz
issue.body:
Here's the actual scene:
      I create an account which type is StatusNet/Custom. But I can't login due to the invalid api.
      Then I delete the app. When I re-install spaz, it only shows a blank card.
      I check the log by command palm-log com.funkatron.app.spaz. It shows "users is not defined in '\libs\BackgroundNotifier.js' line 104"

issue.title: Laconica support not working.
issue.body:
I've been testing Spaz with my local Laconica server and it doesn't display any messages. Account verification works and the account is saved on entering the connection details.  Selecting that account brings up a blank screen with no content. 

I tested the Laconica support with the public Identica server and encountered exactly the same problem. 

Looking at my server logs, no other API requests are received after the initial account_verification request. Is something causing the application to crash before it calls the API methods to retrieve the user's timeline?

issue.title: Back swipe from timeline goes to Login/Search & Explore
issue.body: Should go to accounts list for logging in to other account.

issue.title: Addl scene (?) with full-size user avatar
issue.body: Just need to use profile_image_url.replace(/_normal.(jpg|jpeg|png|gif)/, ".$1") somewhere to reference full-size avatar.

issue.title: Char Countdown doesn't Update After Attaching Image
issue.body: Count remains at 140

issue.title: Insert location link in post
issue.body: We should have a function to insert a google maps link to the current geoloc. Probably an app menu option (we have a lot of buttons already).

issue.title: Mail tweet action
issue.body: This may require some way to determine the web location of the message

issue.title: Type to filter timeline
issue.body: we should be able to start typing on the keyboard in a timeline view, and it should filter the timeline based on our input. needs to be easy to dismiss, and should mirror the look and feel of the standard filter list widget for this (even though we don't use a Mojo list widget).

issue.title: quick access to message actions
issue.body:
We need to implement some kind of quick access to message actions, so you don't have to go to the detail view to do things like reply, RT and favorite.  A couple ideas:
1. click & hold to bring up a popup menu
2. swipe to bring up a popup menu
3. swipe to open up a "drawer" under the message with icons for actions

I did start on some icons for #3, but I think the menu might be a more flexible option

issue.title: Add support for saved searches via Twitter API
issue.body: Need to add to SpazCore, and add UI elements for selecting, adding and removing saved searches. These are stored on a per-account basis

issue.title: "Follow User" button doesn't change state when we're following the user
issue.body: because the data coming from Twitter's API is wrong, the state of the Follow User button doesn't get set properly on setup/activation. We need to work around this, probably by making another request to grab "is A following B" data.

issue.title: Spinner in main timeline not turning off on timeout
issue.body: If we timeout during processing, the spinner doesn't seem to get turned off.

issue.title: Changing search query doesn't clear out results for previous query
issue.body: In a given search scene, if you do one search, then change the query and do another search, the results from the first search remain

issue.title: "View user's recent posts" needs to show errors
issue.body: We need to show an error within the spinner if we can't load the user's timeline

issue.title: My Timeline filter menu should show a checkbox next to the current state
issue.body: yes

issue.title: Should be able to view pics from photo services inline or in detail
issue.body: Currently we have to open a browser to view a pic. We should be able to view them within the app.

issue.title: User's favs should be available through their user detail scene
issue.body: Yep

issue.title: fix cyphertexts with 0A at the end
issue.body:
The code was using $ where it should have been using \z, effectively discarding newlines at the end of the ciphertext.  Fixed.

Also brings master up to date with 0.04 (probably a darcs migration issue).

* test/flow/except.pn: use safe `to` syntax until i decide how to remedy.
* tools/compile.c: parser tool fix. memory corruption due to an inflexible buffer.
* tools/greg: suppress warning about unused 'sig', since it's a parse_from rule.
* core: rename pn-ast.c to ast.c and so on, since the parser has shrunk and the pn- prefix has gone away.

* core/table.c: fix Tuple(put) to allow negative numbers or pushing onto the end of the array.
 * core/potion.c: avoid use of the multiline ending, since it hasn't been introduced yet in the new parser.
* doc: adding a description of lick unquoted values and updating the numbers section.
* core/syntax.g: reset P->source after every parse.
* core/string.c: expand byte buffers a bit extra in advance, to avoid so much reallocation.
* core/syntax.g: no need to alloc PNAsm buffer for potion_sig.
* core/syntax.g: merging sig.g here. updating to use reentrant code. still need to get all parser structs stored in gc.

* test: mark some tests as broken that have outdated syntax.
 * core/syntax.g: allow braces and parens to start on a newline.
* core/sig.g: grammar for method signatures in C.
* core: removing ragel and lemon, switching exclusively to peg/leg.
* core/syntax.g: improve nesting of brackets and parens within unquoted licks.
* core/syntax.g: make assignment and prefix operators right-recursive. fix logic operators.

* core/syntax.g: fix number-related parsings.
 * test/numbers/neg.pn: parser isn't going to allow multiple prefix operators for now.
* core/syntax.g: escape codes in strings. newlines swallowed after non-terminal characters.
* core: working to consolidate PNAsm and PNBytes into a single structure.

* core/syntax.g: tuple building problems.
 * core/potion.c: -G flag for using the new parser.
* core/syntax.g: method calls and unquoted licks.
* core/syntax.g: a lot of operators, assignment, keyed tables.
* core/syntax.g: beginning a new parser using a reentrant, hacked peg/leg.
* core/vm-x86.c: optimizing addition, subtration, multiplication and bit negation.
* test/api/potion-test.c: broken eval test. needed to pass closure in as the second arg.
* test/flow/except.pn: evidence that the counter is incrementing.
* core/vm-x86.c: pad the stack 8 bytes on 32-bit, since the `self` slot is getting clobbered.
* core/callcc.c: eliminating use of a register, some 32-bit platforms don't have so many GENERAL_REGS.
* test/classes/creature.pn: another test of subclasses and methods.
* core/gc.c: deleting strings from the table that have fallen out of use.
* core: allow safe compilation on non-x86, although continuations and jit will not function for now.
* core: object inspection methods may use byte strings within, but ultimately return UTF-8 strings.

* core/callcc.c: bug in continuations. needed to send back `self` rather than `cl` from the yield.
 * test: a few tests of continuations.
* core/callcc.c: remaining callee-saved registers on 64-bit. cool, bytecode vm is working!
* core/callcc.c: place callee-saved registers in the continuation.
* test/flow/callcc.pn: remove the test until it works with the bytecode vm.

* core/table.c: `push` and `append` for lists.
 * core/objmodel.c: renamed `callcc` to `here`.
* core: simplifying the forwarding of P->strings and vt->methods lookup tables. anyway, bug in reallocation of vt->methods, needed to be touched.
* test: changing some test numbers with precision problems while floats are in effect.
* core/gc.c: keep continuations constantly in the write barrier, since their contents can change without notice.

* core/gc.c: continuations are scanned just like the normal stack.
 * core/callcc.c: giving continuations their own class.
* core/callcc.c: had the 64-bit #if conditional wrong. eliminated use of %4 in the asm.

* core/callcc.c: return the continuation from `yield`, to be sure it is stored in the variable again.
 * core/table.c: `pop` method for lists.
* core/callcc.c: working on improving the callcc code to honor stack direction.
* core/string.c: fwd byte strings before converting to intern'd strings.

* core/vm-x86.c: fix 4+ argument functions on x86_64.
 * test/closures/long.pn: test of 14 arguments (the present limit.)
* core/string.c: put state in the write barrier if the string table moves.

* core/string.c: Bytes `string` method converts to a UTF-8 string.
 * core/vm-x86.c: fix for callset op.

* core/vm.c: the bytecode vm math is now equivalent to the jit's math.
 * core/number.c: simplifying potion_decimal.
* core/number.c: eliminating arprec code to focus on a double-based struct. may switch to _Decimal64 after some benchmarking. and then will remerge the arprec stuff.
* core: beginning a little decimal representation based on arprec. <http://crd.lbl.gov/~dhbailey/mpdist/>
* core/vm-x86.c: trimming down the ADD and SUB ops by switching edx and eax.
* core/gc.c: first phase should be a minor phase. allocate a rough old area first and then kick it off.
* example/recursive.pn: an (old?) shootout example testing recursion. need to do floats.
* core: added WAVY bitwise negation operator.
* core: finessing the compiler to do normal binding in the case of no arguments present. previous checkin had problems with optional arguments.
* core: when calling messages, allow immediate dispatch if the message receives no arguments. (avoiding use of: table () ('key') syntax)
* core/vm-x86.c: removing the jit's inline cache, the code is so irrelevant i'll need to start over.
* core/gc.h: small scripts don't need megs. estimate a good birth size based on amount needed and size of the older gen.
* core/pn-scan.rl: fix for table-only lick nodes.

* core/pn-scan.rl: allowing flexible unquoted strings in licks.
 * test/data/grammar.pn: rough sketch of a peg-style grammar done in unquoted strings.
* core/compile.c: empty closures and tables bug. thanks, @henkboom!
* core: eliminating the inline method cache from C. i'll get back to this once methods can be stored in a fixed memory area.
* core/file.c: load environment variables in the Env table.
* core/vm-x86.c: fix for LOADK op in the jit. problems reaching beyond 10 or so entries in the `values` array.
* core/pn-gram.y: allow a newline or separator before a square bracket.

* core/pn-scan.rl: passing syntax errors through an Error object.
 * core/potion.c: print errors from the interactive mode and script run.
* core/string.c: another malloc gone. added potion_str_format for building strings from c using printf's syntax.

* core: hi, everybody. this work i'm checking in surrounds the representation of hash tables in memory. i'm trying to squeeze down the size they take up. potion has three different types of hash tables: the basic table, the method table, and the strings table. this is the last object structure to be moved into gc (there are only two small malloc calls left in Potion.) previously, a basic hash table would take up 48 bytes of overhead on 64-bit. in addition, the table object was split into two parts: the immutable table object and a mutable table array. with this code, the table overhead is 24 bytes and the objects are combined. this means every table object is mutable and will move about in memory (like lists already do.) the total cost of a hashtable is now: 24 bytes + 4 bytes for every 16 pairs + each pair (8 bytes * 2). for comparison, a list is 16 bytes + each item (8 bytes).

Grouping details about op codes in compile.c

Previously there were two arrays statically initalized to hold the list
of op code names, and the op code arg counts. This patch makes a single
array of a struct which holds both the name and the arg count.

Hopefully this change will make it easier to add op codes; less counting
of values in the array to find the right spot to add the op arg count.

micro optimization: use lea instruction rather than add/or

changed compiler macro so gcc generates the lea instruction, and shaved
a byte (or two for x86-64) off each X86_MATH().  this used to be faster,
but i have no idea whether it makes a difference to a modern processor.

specifically, converting to a tagged integer (PN_NUM(i) and X86_MATH)
generates lea eax, [1+eax+eax*1] (opcode 8d 44 00 01) instead of add
eax, eax/or eax, 1 (01 c0 83 c8 01).

* core/number.c: starting bignum/float representation. a note about this. a lot of languages use this style of storing bignums. ruby, python, libtommath, etc. the trick to fast bignum operations isn't the math, in my opinion. it's memory allocation. if you're doing an iterative fibonacci, for instance, you could end up with millions of allocations between the math operations. so, i want to optimize this in the vm by offering bignum registers that are reused. in the case of the fib, we'd have five registers and no other allocations. assignments would simply overwrite those registers.
* core/potion.c: it looks like the __APPLE__ def indicates any flavor of darwin. i guess we'll see.

* core/potion.c: going with quag's printf hack on osx. it appears that osx does some trick to initialize stdout. probably to accomodate stdout piped to Console.app in GUI apps. anyway, the JIT messes with this. my guess is that inside printf it's trying to trace back through the call stack to find out if you're in a GUI app or not. and it can't trace back through potion's function pointers. however, fflush(stdout) doesn't seem to fix the problem.
* core/compile.c: translated the locals dump wrong a few commits ago.
* core/string.c: okay, pn_printf args working. varargs. it's been awhile.

* core/string.c: adding reallocation of size to the byte buffer. pn_printf for formatting c strings and appending them.
 * core: on all objects, inspect now returns a string representation. i still need to fix some printf calls in potion_source_compile.
Adding test for packing numbers in bytecode

* core: multiple args in the bytecode VM. the compiler flattens all argument lists into a series of getlocal/getupval calls, to avoid creating tuples all over the place. with optional or omitted arguments, i'll need to pass in a tuple, however. the idea here is to make sure that we still give every potion closure a concrete c function signature.

* core/vm.c: fantastic. discovered the big problem on x86-64. the stack pointer wasn't being shifted enough. (incidentally, i did some research on callee-saved registers and the only one i need to be careful of is %rbx. i'm not using it anymore, but i think i was using it to lookup pointers previously.) http://www.sun.com/bigadmin/features/articles/amd64_debugging.jsp
* core/compile.c: get rid of OP_MASK, it doesn't work for numbers, as quag points out. just store in PN_OP->a and compare.
* core/opcodes.h: use a mask for the OP_LOADPN check, to cut down the macros.

* core/vm.c: an experimental inline method cache for the jit. this is turned off by default until it proves to be really worth it. i allocate some bytes at the end of the assembled x86 instructions (4 * sizeof(PN) for each method lookup found) and use it to cache a closure. in theory, this is a great way to speed things up because the jumps are small and you're likely to have the same (mixin, method) query happen over and over again at these calls. also the cache is kept with the machine code buffer, so they get released by gc simultaneously. it may not save a whole lot of speed in the end, though, since potion strings are immutable and can be pre-hashed, so lookups are pretty good.

Annotate '-V' byte code listings

For example:

  [12] setlocal 0 2   ; c
  [13] getlocal 0 2   ; c
  [14] notjmp 0 3     ; to 18
  [15] loadpn 0 14    ; false
  [16] setlocal 0 2   ; c
  [17] jump -5	      ; to 13
  [18] loadpn 0 1     ; 0
  [19] setlocal 0 5   ; i
  [20] getlocal 0 5   ; i
  [21] loadpn 1 3     ; 1
  [22] add 0 1
  [23] setlocal 0 5   ; i
Pack small numbers into loadpn instead of loadk
Added simple string slice((start, end)) method

* core/vm.c: i guess __WORDSIZE isn't really a macro on some platforms. PN_SIZE_T it is.
* core/vm.c: flexible allocation of the function buffer, then memcpy into mmap'd section.

AST_OR ('or' and '||') tokens.

Also added test cases for both 'and' and 'or'.

* core/vm.c: an upval issue. first off, having PN_GC be an int was forcing the alignment off. a long ends up being allocated anyway (except in the case of PNTuple.) second, an optimization on upvals. store the pointer without the REF_FLAG. the fact that it's in the upvals registers indicates that it's a ref.

• Make `test` depend on `potion`.
  Some tests, like the VM tests, try to invoke `potion`, so let’s generate it.

• Use `/bin/echo` in Makefile.
  This guarantees that `-n` is available, and works regardless of the shell invoked.

commit.message: Added summary to FreeBusy. Moved RRule class. Added orig_value to RRule.

up to 1.1.0.1 for github based on mauricio's patch

Signed-off-by: Jo Potts <jopotts@gmail.com>

From: Mauricio Gomes <mauricio@edge14.com>

"I was having trouble parsing an ICS file and I kept getting this error:

NotImplementedError: Value of type (Bignum) does not support to_ical
method! from component.rb:223:in `sequence'

I looked through the ICS file and noticed the sequence numbers were
really large, (ie, 12055194070). After looking through the RFC,
section 4.3.8 defines the valid range for "integer" as -2147483648 to
2147483647. Numbers that large in Ruby get converted to Bignum, but
the to_ical() method doesn't support it."

Signed-off-by: Jo Potts <jopotts@gmail.com>

the following passes in timezone id from the calendar to events built in
the calendar, which ensures that when you got to ical string format
dates are correctly embedded.
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/netshade/icalendar into netshade

add ical_properties to dates & datetimes which lets us tuck timezones
in there and serialize them correctly

Added timezone awareness to datetime attributes

DateTime now has icalendar_tzid and icalendar_tzid= methods

This is to provide support for conformance with RFC 2445 Section 4.3.5, when PARSING icalendar input

Parsing a component property which is a datetime will set this to:

   UTC if the value for the datetime ends with Z, e.g. DTSTART:19970903T163000Z
      corresponding to FORM #2, DATE WITH UTC TIME in the RFC
   The specified TZID parameter value if specified in the attribute line, e.g. 	DTSTART;TZID=America/Chicago:19970903T163000
      corresponding to FORM #3 DATE WITH LOCAL TIME AND TIMEZONE REFERENCE
   nil otherwise, e.g.  DTSTART:19970903T163000
      corresponding to FORM #1 DATE WITH LOCAL TIME

The datetime is NOT adjusted for timezone when the property is parsed.
The adjustment SHOULD be done using the timezone components in the containing calendar, however it may be possible to use
the TZInfo gem to do the conversion when processing input from google calendar, and ical.app on the Macintosh since both
seem to use tzids which are in the Olsen Timezone database used by TZInfo and  MS Outlook seems to output datetimes in FORM #2.

Since I currently have no need to export icalendar format with anything other than FORM 2 datetimes, there is minimal support for export.
The only thing I have done is to output either a FORM 2, or FORM 1 value string for a datetime depending on whether or not icalendar_tzid is set to "UTC"
